spanishExample: ¡Buenas tardes! ¿Has *seen* a esta persona?
englishTranslation: Good afternoon! Have you seen this person?
vocabIncluded: "the personal a": using an extra "a" before a direct object when it's a person
has: "have", "you have" before a participle (Haber, present, 2nd person)

spanishExample: ¡Hazlo y es cierto que él lo sabrá!
englishTranslation: Do it and it’s certain that he will know it!
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
cierto: "certain", used with Ser to express certainty (adjective)
sabrá: "will know", "he/she/it will know" (Saber, future, 3rd person)

spanishExample: ¡Tienes que hacerlo bien de una vez por todas!
englishTranslation: You have to do it right once and for all!
vocabIncluded: "bien": adverb meaning "well", "fine", and a variety of other positive things
de una vez por todas: "once and for all" (idiom)
using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: ¿Adónde fuiste?
englishTranslation: Where did you go?

spanishExample: ¿Cómo le va? ¿Sabe dónde está el tipo?
englishTranslation: (Formal) How is it going? Do you know where the dude is?
vocabIncluded: cómo le va: how's it going? (formal) (idiom)
dónde: adverb meaning "where?" in a question or implied question

spanishExample: ¿Quieres saber lo que ellos sabían?
englishTranslation: Do you want to know what they knew?
vocabIncluded: "lo que": "what" as a connector between phrases

spanishExample: ¿Sabías que esto es mejor que eso?
englishTranslation: Did you know that this is better than that?
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)

spanishExample: Al menos puede hacerlo de esa forma.
englishTranslation: At least he can do it in that way.

spanishExample: De verdad, he querido tener una casa con ellas.
englishTranslation: Really, I’ve wanted to have a house with them(f).
vocabIncluded: ella: "them" after a preposition (fem. prep. pronoun)
he: "have", "I have" before a participle (Haber, present, 1st person)

spanishExample: Desde ya, no quiero que sepan nada.
englishTranslation: As of now, I don’t want them to know anything.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
desde ya: "as of now", "from this moment on" (idiom)

spanishExample: Él es el que estuvo ahí una vez.
englishTranslation: He is the one that was there once.
vocabIncluded: ahí: adverb meaning "there", especially when close to the speaker or listener

spanishExample: El niño no quería que supieran esa parte de la historia.
englishTranslation: The little boy didn’t want them to know that part of the story.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
supieran: "knew", "they knew" (Saber, past subjunctive, 3rd person plural)

spanishExample: Él quiere que ella sepa que no puede tenerte.
englishTranslation: He wants her to know that she can’t have you.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)

spanishExample: Ella sabía que esto era mío.
englishTranslation: She knew this was mine (m).
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)

spanishExample: Ellos siempre hacen los trabajos más rápidos.
englishTranslation: They always do the fastest jobs.

spanishExample: En serio, ¡haz lo que querías hacer!
englishTranslation: Seriously, do what you wanted to do!
vocabIncluded: "lo que": "what" as a connector between phrases

spanishExample: Ese día hubo un poco de *money* para el trabajo.
englishTranslation: That day there was a little bit of money for the job.

spanishExample: Ese tipo estuvo aquí por un tiempo.
englishTranslation: That dude was here for a while.

spanishExample: Espero que haya menos gente.
englishTranslation: I hope there are less people.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
espero:  hope/wait/expect, I  hope/wait/expect  (Esperar, present, 1st person)

spanishExample: Está en un lugar seguro, bajo *the table.*
englishTranslation: He is in a safe place under the table.
vocabIncluded: seguro: adjective meaning "safe" or "secure" when used with Ser

spanishExample: Estará aquí menos tiempo, o sea, solo tres horas.
englishTranslation: He’ll be here less time, that is, only three hours.
vocabIncluded: estará: "will be", "he/she/it will be" (Estar, future, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Esto es muy serio. ¡Ellas no *me saw!*
englishTranslation: This is very serious. They(f) didn’t see me!

spanishExample: Ha hecho todo contra el tuyo.
englishTranslation: He has done everything against yours(m).
vocabIncluded: ha: "has", "he/she/it has" before a participle (Haber, present, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Hicimos lo que queríamos.
englishTranslation: We did what we wanted.
vocabIncluded: "lo que": "what" as a connector between phrases

spanishExample: Irá a la fiesta y *he’ll see* lo que hice.
englishTranslation: He will go to the party and he’ll see what I did.
vocabIncluded: "lo que": "what" as a connector between phrases
irá: "will go", "he/she/it will go" (Ir, future, 3rd person)

spanishExample: La hija que lo sabía lo *said* durante la fiesta.
englishTranslation: The daughter that knew it said it during the party.

spanishExample: Lo hicieron sobre la casa sin cuidado.
englishTranslation: They did it on top of the house without caution.

spanishExample: Lo mejor de la casa es la gran *entrance.*
englishTranslation: The best thing about the house is the great entrance(f).
vocabIncluded: gran: "big"/"grand" when used right before a noun (adjective)

spanishExample: Lo sabríamos si nos lo *they told,* pero no lo sabemos.
englishTranslation: We would know it if they told us, but we don’t know it.
vocabIncluded: nos: "us" as an indirect object ("to us", "for us")
sabríamos: "would know", "we would know" (Saber, conditional, 1st person plural)

spanishExample: Me podrías *to tell* y yo lo sabría.
englishTranslation: You would be able to tell me and I would know it.
vocabIncluded: me: "me" as an indirect object ("to me", "for me")
podrías: "would be able", "you would be able" (Poder, conditional, 2nd person)
sabría: "would know", "I would know" (Saber, conditional, 1st person)

spanishExample: Mi mamá puede tener lo que quiera.
englishTranslation: My mom can have whatever she wants.
vocabIncluded: "lo que": "what" as a connector between phrases

spanishExample: No está segura de que yo pueda tener una casa grande.
englishTranslation: She isn’t sure that I can have a big house.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
pueda: "be able", "I be able" (Poder, subjunctive, 1st person)
seguro: adjective meaning "sure" when used with Estar

spanishExample: No ha ido a ese lado del lugar.
englishTranslation: He hasn’t gone to that side of the place.
vocabIncluded: del: "of the" before a masculine noun
ha: "has", "he/she/it has" before a participle (Haber, present, 3rd person)

spanishExample: No podía hacer eso con mi familia.
englishTranslation: I wasn’t able to do that with my family.
vocabIncluded: podía: "was able", "I was able" (Poder, imperfect, 1st person)

spanishExample: No podía ser la única persona ahí.
englishTranslation: He wasn’t able to be the only person there.
vocabIncluded: ahí: adverb meaning "there", especially when close to the speaker or listener
podía: "was able", "he/she/it was able" (Poder, imperfect, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Nos *he saw* hace dos semanas.
englishTranslation: He saw us two weeks ago.

spanishExample: Por cierto, ella tendría que irse si tú supieras la verdad.
englishTranslation: By the way, she would have to leave if you knew the truth.
vocabIncluded: irse: any use of Ir with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to "leave"
tendría: "would have", "he/she/it would have" (Tener, conditional, 3rd person)
using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: Puede estar en contra de la nueva *law.*
englishTranslation: He might be opposed to the new law(f).

spanishExample: Puede que yo no quisiera ir.
englishTranslation: It might be that I didn’t want to go.

spanishExample: Queremos hacer *the cake* con esa forma.
englishTranslation: We want to make the cake with that shape.

spanishExample: Quiere que lo haga desde ya, a menos que no lo sepa.
englishTranslation: She wants me to do it from now on, unless I don’t know it.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
desde ya: "as of now", "from this moment on" (idiom)

spanishExample: Quiere que sepamos un poco de la historia.
englishTranslation: She wants us to know a little bit of the story.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)

spanishExample: Quiero que sepas que *these colors* son vivos.
englishTranslation: I want you to know that these colors are lively.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
vivo: "lively" for events/objects (adjective typically used with Ser)

spanishExample: Saben que no había tiempo.
englishTranslation: They know there wasn’t time.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
había: "there was/were" indicating existence (Haber, imperfect, impersonal)

spanishExample: Sabes que tu hijo *eats* al mismo tiempo que tu hermana.
englishTranslation: You know your son eats at the same time as your sister.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
al mismo tiempo: "at the same time" (idiom)

spanishExample: Sabíamos que ella estaba viva desde que éramos niños.
englishTranslation: We knew she was alive since we were kids.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)

spanishExample: Sabrán que teníamos que estar aquí desde esta mañana.
englishTranslation: They will know that we had to be here since this morning.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
sabrán: "will know", "they will know" (Saber, future, 3rd person plural)
using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: Sabré que es para él.
englishTranslation: I will know that it’s for him.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
sabré: "will know", "I will know" (Saber, future, 1st person)

spanishExample: Sabremos que hay una razón para ir hacia *that town.*
englishTranslation: We’ll know there is a reason for going toward that town.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
hay: "there is/are" indicating existence (Haber, present, impersonal)
para: "in order", "in order to" before an infinitive
sabremos: "will know", "we will know" (Saber, future, 1st person plural)

spanishExample: Sea lo que sea, vamos a hacerlo.
englishTranslation: Whatever it is, we’re going to do it.
vocabIncluded: sea lo que sea: "whatever it is" (idiom)
using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")

spanishExample: Si hubiera más personas, tus hermanos sabrían la verdad.
englishTranslation: If there were more people, your brothers would know the truth.
vocabIncluded: hubiera: "there were to be" (Haber, past subjunctive, impersonal)
sabrían: "would know", "they would know" (Saber, conditional, 3rd person plural)

spanishExample: Si la niña lo supiera, tú también lo sabrías.
englishTranslation: If the little girl knew it, you also would know it.
vocabIncluded: sabrías: "would know", "you would know" (Saber, conditional, 2nd person)

spanishExample: Si pudiera hacerlo como él, estaría feliz, sobre todo a esta hora.
englishTranslation: If I were able to do it like him, I would be happy, especially at this hour.
vocabIncluded: estaría: "would be", "I would be" (Estar, conditional, 1st person)
pudiera: "were able", "I were able" (Poder, subjunctive past, 1st person)

spanishExample: Si quisiera ir, yo sí tendría dónde estar.
englishTranslation: If I wanted to go, I would have a place to be.
vocabIncluded: sí: adverb meaning "indeed" or otherwise providing positive emphasis
tendría: "would have", "I would have" (Tener, conditional, 1st person)

spanishExample: Si quisieran hacer eso entre las tres casas, lo harían.
englishTranslation: If they wanted to do that between the three houses, they would do it.
vocabIncluded: harían: "would do/make", "they would do/make" (Hacer, conditional, 3rd person plural)
quisieran: "wanted", "they wanted" (Querer, past subjunctive, 3rd person plural)

spanishExample: Si quisieras tenerlo, ella lo sabría.
englishTranslation: If you wanted to have it, she would know it.
vocabIncluded: sabría: "would know", "he/she/it would know" (Saber, conditional, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Si se lo *I told,* lo sabrían.
englishTranslation: If I told them it, they would know it.
vocabIncluded: "se" to mean "le" or "les", as in "se lo" or "se la"
sabrían: "would know", "they would know" (Saber, conditional, 3rd person plural)

spanishExample: Si solo supiera su nombre, mi esposa estaría feliz.
englishTranslation: If I only knew her name, my wife would be happy.
vocabIncluded: estaría: "would be", "he/she/it would be" (Estar, conditional, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Su papá no está muerto.
englishTranslation: Their dad isn’t dead.

spanishExample: Supe que eso era lo que ella quería.
englishTranslation: I found out that was what she wanted.
vocabIncluded: "lo que": "what" as a connector between phrases
"que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
supe: "knew / found out", "I knew / found out" (Saber, preterite, 1st person)

spanishExample: Supo que ella tenía un esposo.
englishTranslation: He found out that she had a husband.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
supe: "knew / found out", "he/she/it knew / found out" (Saber, preterite, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Tiempo al tiempo; que yo sepa, era suyo.
englishTranslation: Give it time; as far as I know, it was his.
vocabIncluded: que yo sepa: "as far as I know" (idiom)

spanishExample: Tienes que saber la verdad, sobre todo porque él la ha sabido.
englishTranslation: You have to know the truth, especially because he has known it.
vocabIncluded: ha: "has", "he/she/it has" before a participle (Haber, present, 3rd person)
using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: Tienes razón, este es el lugar donde tu madre tuvo esa idea.
englishTranslation: You’re right, this is the place where your mother had that idea.
vocabIncluded: tener razón: "to be right" (idiom, lit. "to have reason")
